From: "Mark Baker" <distobj@...>
>
> On Mon, Feb 24, 2003 at 10:44:40AM -0500, Seairth Jacobs wrote:
> > If "mortal" isn't recognized at all, then what?  It seems to me that 404
is
> > the correct response, but I wanted to make sure...
>
> I've used 404 myself, but I could think of good reasons not to.
>
> If there was some set of query params that identified the "primary
> key" for the resource, then additional parameters could safely be
> ignored such that GET returned the same representations as for the
> URI with only the primary key params specified.  In theory, it may be
> useful to return a 302 response back to this primary URI; in practice,
> it's certainly not worth the extra round trip, so probably fine to
> just return the same representations on a 200 until new parameters
> are supported.

Hmm... I suppose you could also just return a Content-Location: header with
the 200 response.  On the other hand, this effectively allows others to
extend the URL with your implicit permission.  For instance, suppose someone
chose to add their own query parameter which they used in their own system
for some reason or other.  Now, suppose at a later point in time, you decide
to add a new query parameter to your system which just happens to be the
same name as someone else's parameter name.  Potentially, you could cause
unexpected side effects for that link that's already out there.  Admittedly,
it's unlikely that this scenario would happen, but there's a lot about the
web today that I would have said the same thing about yesterday.

> If you expect your primary key may change, then a 404 approach
> probably makes good sense.

In this case, I do not have the pk in the query string.  I have just
finished writing a new blog system (didn't like any of the ones I found),
trying to use the REST architecture as much as possible.  I still have a
long way to go, but the first version is up and running(?) at
http://www.seairth.com/blog. In this case, the query string is only used to
fetch html-based forms for adding/editing folders and entries.  For
instance, suppose I have an folder whose URL is:

http://www.seairth.com/blog/blogg

(yes, it actually exists)  If you do a GET on that URL, you will get back an
appropriate representation of the resource.  Now, if I wanted to create a
new subfolder or entry, I would POST the appropriate message to that URL.
This could be done by writing a gui application similar to what Joe Gregorio
has done with his blog system.  However, since I don't have ony yet, I opted
to use html-based forms.  In order to fetch the appropriate form, I would
use a URL like:

http://www.seairth.com/blog/blogg?form=addentry

(yes, it exists, but is protected)  This would return to me an html form,
which would in turn just POST to the URL (without the query string).  At the
end of the day, it all works really, really well.  So far, anyhow.  :)

---
Seairth Jacobs
